content: this is easily one of the most important
and most favorite tools in my shop but it isn't without its flaws and today I
want to talk about those hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic craft the
procs on thermo cut hot wire table I use it all the time it's crucial for what I
do while I have talked at length in videos about how you can work around not
having one of these having one of these unlocks a huge amount of potential for
crafting and terrain building for the types of things I build it allows me to
do certain things I can't do with a knife and it allows me to do a lot of
the things I can do with a knife a lot faster and more accurate so needless to
say I love it and I rely on it heavily but it's not a perfect tool it's kind of
a cheaply made thing and I think for a lot of what we do in this hobby it gets
pushed a little bit beyond its limits and there's some things that you have to
work around and some things that constantly see people get frustrated
with so today I'm going to talk about those flaws and how I cope with them or
deal with them the first thing is this factory guide and if you go to the
comments section of any Facebook post where people are discussing this tool
one of the things you will come across is people complaining about this guide
and some of those complaints are totally justified and I think some of them are
misinformed the misinformed one I think is that people complain that this thing
slides around and moves too freely but the thing is that's on purpose this
isn't just a rip fence it's also a crosscut sled so that means you want
this to slide freely so it's actually great that it does that and it's
important to keep that in mind some people also I think are a little bit
misguided on the fact that this angle is a little bit hard to set perfectly true
but the thing is it actually doesn't matter how this is set when you are just
ripping a piece through this way you want to do a long
cut like a table saw cut doesn't matter if this is out of true 90 degrees or at
an angle because you are cutting on a very small point not a long saw blade so
all that matters is the distance between here if you have this at an angle it's
still going to be a straight cut but the one complaint that is a very big deal
about this that people really get upset about is that there's no way to lock
this in on the end and it kind of flexes and it moves and people get really upset
about that and they get wavy cuts that's a really easy problem to solve all you
do is put your hand on it that's it just hold it and then it's secure and you
push it through because this tool is not a big production tool where you're meant
to be cutting huge sheets you're doing little delicate hobby stuff so you use
one hand to hold your material and one hand to hold the guide and that's it
it's not that complicated that being said I don't see why they
didn't just make a mechanism to lock this in place they absolutely could have
an absolutely should have as it would have saved people a lot of grief but
none of those flaws are things that I care about the problem I have with this
guide is its height it's only like 2 centimeters tall and one of the main
things I use this tool for is ripping down foam into thinner material because
this guide is so short that means it's very difficult to hold this material
plumb and you can end up with angled cut so you want something that is taller and
that's where aftermarket guides come in I use this guide err Pro from shifting
lands calm and it is absolutely ideal for me because it has this tall rip
fence which means that I can place material here put it up against that
fence and keep it plumb and true as I guide the foam through the machine
absolutely crucial you need something like this now you don't need to go and
buy it though this is a very simple jig you could absolutely make this yourself
just with some MDF or some cardboard or whatever get creative you just need
something that is tall and a 90 degree angle to the
table but if you do want to buy one Gerard at shipping Lancome makes this
one that is ready to go and is great this is the guide er Pro he also has the
guide er pro 2.0 which has two extra features one is this little cutout at
the bottom which allows you to make a wider cut the maximum distance you can
get the defense away from the wire is bigger and it has this removable piece
and the reason for this is that it has this groove here so that if you want to
set this wire to an angle like say 45 degrees it can actually pass through
here and you can still use this as a rip fence personally I tend to not use this
one very much because I find it to be bigger and more cumbersome I actually
like the original guider Pro better but those features are handy and if you're
only getting one it may be worth considering getting that one now an
interesting thing about this is that it doesn't have a locking mechanism so
remember what I said on this one it's easy to solve the problem because you
use your free hand to hold it well this one it doesn't have a locking mechanism
so while this one won't flex and move like that one does you still need to
hold it and actually has this big handle here for you to do so you are only using
one hand to guide your material it's just something you have to learn and get
used to that being said there is a little trick if you want to lock it in
place so you can free up both hands the bottom of this just has a little wood
rail that sits in this guide and if you want to lock it in it's just a matter of
taking a little piece of paper towel setting it where you want it and then
pushing it in and that little bit of extra friction will actually hold it in
place so you can free up your spare hand and use it that way these are made out
of wood some of them come with an MDF strip I think some of them might come
with a hardwood strip and depending on where you live and your humidity level
in your home this may expand and contract to yours and may be tighter or
looser than mine so adjust accordingly if you find it to be too tight you can
sand it down a little bit if you find it to be too loose so you can use the paper
towel method but that's that now when you want to actually cut you need to set
this wire and you want this wire for most cuts to be exactly 90 degrees
the work surface so that if you pass material through against your 90 degree
fence you don't get an angled cut so in order to do that you need something to
age the wire all you do is loosen this and get it square you can use a
carpenter's square my carpenter's square is a little bit too big it actually goes
past which means I can't get it close to this wire I can still use it and eyeball
the space between the two and get it right or you can get a smaller carpenter
square or just one of these plastic triangles from a little geometry set and
that can set your wire or if you are using a taller rip fence that you know
is true you can actually just use this and set the wire to the fence like
anything this takes a bit of practice and you have to keep in mind how crucial
it is if you're just cutting thin material it doesn't matter if it's a
tiny bit out but if you're ripping really tall material obviously that
tangle is going to be more crucial adjusting this wire is where I think the
biggest flaw in this machine lies it's easy to adjust the wire left to right on
the work surface to be true but for certain cuts you actually need this wire
to be true front to back let's say you want to push
in material this way and then move it if this wire is angled front to back and
you push material through this way that angle is going to transfer to that cut
and you probably don't want that this is where it kind of sucks is that this wire
sits in a little groove and there's no way to adjust this and it seems like
some people get machines where it's just true out of the box and some it's out
slightly and some it's out a lot you can kind of try to bend it square that sort
of sucks underneath this is where it's mounted you can use some small shims in
here loosen up the set screw put some small shims in here and try to get it
right that's really tricky and probably takes a lot of tries to get it right but
it is a nice permanent solution or you can just ignore this groove entirely
let's say you need to adjust this wire slightly more toward
the back at the top here don't use the groove just set it pull it really tight
until you get it where you want it it's pretty simple it's not ideal because
that could move but I found that testing that out it actually does stay fairly
secure if you are really concerned about it you could cut a little groove in
there to hold the wire permanently thankfully mine out of the box was
pretty good and I don't have to worry about that I would say that if yours
ends up being way out like more than like a millimeter or so maybe talk to
procs on or replacement because that's not right it shouldn't it shouldn't be
that far out now another tip in terms of adjusting the wire is that you can
loosen all this and set this wire at any angle you want and you may be tempted to
set it at something like 45 degrees and 90 degrees and then mark it on top here
with a marker so that you can quickly and easily put it right back and I did
that when I had this tool early on but as you can see my 90 degree mark is way
out from what is actually true I don't know exactly why that is but I think
that this flex and maybe things changing over time those marks proved to be very
inaccurate long term so I wouldn't bother doing something like that so now
you have your machine all up set up to plumb it's true you got your guide
sorted out and you look at the temperature dial it goes from 1 to 10
and this temperature dial is actually the main and most important feature of
this tool and what sets it apart from a lot of Cheaper models is that you can
adjust this and that's really important because the thicker your foam is the
denser it is the hotter you need that wire to be and the faster you want to
cut the hotter you need it to be so there's a lot of adjustment that needs
to take place from different foam to different foam and different types of
cuts you're looking for a magic number I know a lot of people ask what is the
magic number there's a little guide here that says some thicknesses and
temperatures I never used them you got to do it by feel and essentially I like
to just start out around 2 or 3 and then just test if your wire is too hot it's
going to cut through this way too easily and it's going to make a really wide cut
if you have it set to cool it's gonna take a lot of pressure and force and
you'll start to see this wire really bending and you know you got to turn it
up so you got to just get a feel for it and adjust it to the thickness and
density of the foam that you're using but you also have to adjust it to the
speed that you're cutting you said the slower you cut the lower you want
the temperature because if it's too high and you're cutting slow it's gonna make
those really wide burns if you're cutting really fast and your wire is set
to cool then you're gonna put a lot of force on the wire and that's what's
gonna cause snapping you really just have to get used to it just spend an
hour to when you first get this thing playing with different foams testing out
the temperature and get used to adjusting it as you're working and after
a while you'll start to learn what works best if you're using white EPS foam the
cut ball stuff it's gonna melt way faster and easier than this stuff for
this XPS well which is much denser you may find that the numbers on here are
hard to read so you could just take some white paint and highlight those numbers
I've never bothered because I just got used to feeling for you can feel where
it maxes out on each end eventually you have to get good at doing it by feel
anyway so I don't think the visual reference is that important
now speaking of temperature what makes this tool really great and makes working
with foam a lot safer is that you can adjust the temperature to cut the foam
at a correct safe temperature now when using a hot wire and foam of any kind
you want to have some ventilation open a window set up a fan if you have a hood
fan great but at least you want to have some ventilation if you're cutting this
at the correct temperature it's only melting the foam and emitting some white
smoke which yeah you don't want to be breathing that in but the the really bad
dangerous smoke is when this stuff combusts when it burns and it burns
black you don't want that you don't want to be
breathing that stuff it's really nasty for you and one of the reasons that
happens is because the wire is too hot or because when you finish a cut a
little piece see a little piece gets stuck on there and it starts melting and
burning you don't want that so what you want to get used to doing is when you're
doing a cut you want to get used to turning the power off immediately after
so that last little bit doesn't stay and burn on the wire so you got to practice
that takes another free hand which can be difficult when you're already doing
different stuff so proxxon actually does sell a foot pedal switch so it works
like a sewing machine plug it into this thing and use your foot to turn the
machine on and off and that's a really great really handy and I think that's
the best way to use this machine I don't own one yet I haven't bothered to buy
one I probably should because I think it makes this tool a lot easier to use and
a lot safer the other reason that's important is that if you leave those
little pieces burning on your wire that residue will eventually gum up this
little hole that holds the wire and you will run into the last problem with this
tool which is changing the wire when it snaps let me tell you this wire will
snap you will break it over time thankfully these machines come with
something like a 97 feet of wire and you only use like six inches at a times they
have like 180 snaps worth of wire don't buy an extra roll when you buy this
thing I've had this for four or so years use it a lot and I haven't lost on my
wire left you will not run out for a long time unless you're doing something
very very wrong but you will inevitably snap these wires
there's a couple reasons one is that you're just putting too much stress on
the wire your temperature is wrong and it just pushes and it snaps it's a very
delicate wire the other reason is that maybe you've been working with it
properly for a really long time and the wire just wears out and it gets thinner
and all that heat it just gets thinner and it snaps it's gonna happen so you
have to adjust it so the first thing I do is when it snaps is take out the wire
you open this tension knob here release it pull out the little piece of broken
wire and this is really important because
start to get stuck in there and they build up over time and when you go to
stick your new wire through you may not be able to feed it through and people
run into the problem all the time where they can't get that wire back into the
hole so the first thing you want to do is turn it over and see if there's any
little wires sticking out the bottom if there are just pull them out from the
bottom and clear up that hole you may also have excess melted foam built up in
there and if that's the case you want to get yourself a very very very fine
needle something as fine as this wire to poke through and clean it out and if
that doesn't work you can use some acetone acetone melts styrofoam so if
you just pour a little bit in there and it will dissolve that residue and clean
out the wire but be careful when you're pouring it because acetone will also
remove this text and guidelines printed on top of your machine and you don't
want that and it will pour through this bottom hole and drip onto your cutting
mat and it will also remove the printed lines on your cutting mat I learned that
the hard way once so put a paper towel underneath and be careful pouring it
through poke a pin through make sure this is opened up all the way and you
should be able to feed it through no problem and retighten it and then it's
just a matter of tightening this wire spool again and you're good to go now
you don't want this to be too tight if it's super super tight it's gonna snap
really easily but if it's too loose it's gonna Bend and move on you keep in mind
when you heat the wire it will expand and become looser so you want it to be a
little bit tighter than you want it's hard to explain again like the
temperature you have to get used to it you will break a few wires and
eventually you will learn what's an ideal tension on this thing it's
something kind of like that also note that if you're doing a lot of cuts at a
high temperature it's going to really stretch this wire out so it's not a bad
idea to stop every once in a while and turn the wire off and let it quickly
cool and get smaller let all those molecules come back together and
a little bit tighter and you may have to put some more tension on it after a
bunch of cuts it's also really important that when you feed this wire over you
make sure it all stays on the spool and doesn't run underneath or on top
sometimes people will go to do a cut and they'll see their wires not heating up
this machine creates a circuit so if the wire is not heating up usually that
means that the circuit isn't complete so maybe it's not connected down here to
the set screw but more than likely up here it's not connected to the spool as
nicely and it's running underneath so just make sure all that is nice and neat
and tidy and everything is sitting where it should that's really it I think
there's probably some other issues that people run into that I forgotten about
and if I did if there's a problem you're having regularly with this tool let me
know in the comments section and I'll try to answer it there these are just
the things off the top of my head that I know I have struggled with throughout
the years so hopefully that helps get you started if you like this video hit
the like button let me know in the comments if you want to pick one of
these up too kind of up your crafting or terrain building game head over to
Blackmagic craft CA there I have my essential equipment page with links to
this and most of the other stuff that I use regularly and lastly if you really
like this video and you want help me keep making videos like this or the
build videos that I usually do you can help me do that by supporting the
channel on patreon patreon is one of the main reasons that I'm able to do this
panel full-time and make a video every week for the community so you want to
help me keep doing it that is the best way you can do it check it out love to
have you as the newest member of the black magic craft fellowship that's it
for this week guys hope you enjoyed see you again next week
Cheers you
